review.title: Plagiarism Detection in Polyphonic Music using Monaural Signal Separation
review.abstract: Given the large number of new musical tracks released each year, automated approaches to plagiarism detection are essential to help us track potential violations of copyright. Most current approaches to plagiarism detection are based on musical similarity measures, which typically ignore the issue of polyphony in music. We present a novel feature space for audio derived from compositional modelling techniques, commonly used in signal separation, that provides a mechanism to account for polyphony without incurring an inordinate amount of computational overhead. We employ this feature representation in conjunction with traditional audio feature representations in a classification framework which uses an ensemble of distance features to characterize pairs of songs as being plagiarized or not. Our experiments on a database of about 3000 musical track pairs show that the new feature space characterization produces significant improvements over standard baselines.

sections.heading: 3. Feature Representations from compositional models
sections.text: Our feature space design is primarily motivated by the fact that most current approaches do not explicitly address the problem of polyphony in recordings, but simply use a monophonic approach, while others view polyphony as a more general multi-dimensional mathematical problem. While an ideal solution to this problem would be to separate the many notes or voices in the recording into different tracks, this would require information for each track that is likely to be unavailable. We are introducing a new feature set based on the compositional representation of the size spectrum. Specifically, we are using a non-negative matrix factorization (NMF) -based embedding for the music tracks [6], which we expect will take polyphony much better into account than the feature sets traditionally used for music rendering. These NMF-based features are used in conjunction with traditional feature representations. In the following, we first describe the NMF-based feature extraction section, and then briefly describe the NMF-based feature extraction section for traditionally used feature audio.

sections.text: In addition to the characteristics extracted from the NMF, we extract characteristics that use traditional methods of audio content analysis that effectively describe temporal and spectral sound structures. We expect that the addition of these characteristics to the NMF-based characteristics will lead to increased efficiency in the detection of similar music documents in polyphonic environments. sections.heading: 3.3. Distance Features for Pair Characterization
sections.text: In the previous subsections, we described the sets of characteristics extracted for each track. We use these characteristics to calculate distances that we use to characterize trace pairs as plagiarized or not. Given the feature presentations for the two tracks, we use the Dynamic Time Warping (DTW) algorithm to calculate distances between the corresponding trace sequences. Dynamic Time Distortion is a dynamic programming algorithm that efficiently calculates the optimal alignment of nonlinear extended or contracted sequences. Based on an inspection of the dataset, we observed that the music in a pair of plagiarized tracks is usually different in rhythm, while maintaining other characteristics that make it sound similar. We incorporate this intuition into our distance calculation by using a modified version of the DTW algorithm for rhythm-based characteristics (with local weights).

sections.heading: 4. Experimental Results
sections.text: We used the MIRToolBox in MATLAB [11] to extract the traditional audio-based characteristics described in Section 3.2, followed by extraction of the NMF characteristics and DTW-based distance calculation to characterize tracks in pairs, as in Section 3. These distance characteristics and true class names for the training data were then used to train a random forest classifier [12] with 150 trees.

sections.heading: 4.1. Dataset
sections.text: We created a database of 2966 song pairs, consisting of 966 plagiarized (positive data sets) and 2000 unplagiarized (negative data sets) song pairs. The positive instances were obtained from music covers and plagiarism lawsuits [13, 14], including the Music Copyright Infringement Resource of the UCLA School of Law. The data set consists of music from a wide range of genres and languages. sections.text: We compare the performance of 3 systems based on the test data. We use the traditional sets of features described in Section 3.2 as a starting point and compare them to performance only using the NMF features and an extended set of features using the basic features along with NMF features. sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text: We formulated the task of plagiarism detection within a supervised classification framework that uses distance characteristics across pairs of music tracks to learn the model, and our approach resulted in a significant improvement in performance over baseline metrics. It should be noted that our method does not do without agencies that track potential copyright infringement. Ideally, it should be used as a filtering mechanism to identify extremely similar music tracks. In this work, we used sample foundations derived from the data for NMF - alternative methods of learning the basics (such as training the baseline set from the data, using examples of expected notes for initialization) and effects of changing the baseline set size are guidelines that we expect to explore in future workflows. NMF-based representation of features should also be useful in other tasks dealing with polyphonic music.
